title: 115_hr5422
content:
The "Death Tax Repeal Act" is cited as the short title. It repeals estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Death Tax Repeal Act terminates the application of estate taxes for decedents dying after its enactment, with exceptions for distributions from qualified domestic trusts related to decedents before the Act's enactment date. The Death Tax Repeal Act ends estate taxes for individuals who pass away after the Act is enacted, excluding certain distributions from qualified domestic trusts linked to individuals who died before the Act's effective date. Section 2664 of the tax code states that generation-skipping transfers are not subject to tax after the Act's enactment. Section 2664 of the tax code states that generation-skipping transfers are not subject to tax after the Death Tax Repeal Act is enacted. Amendments related to gift tax computation are also made, specifying the tax amounts for each calendar year. The tax code specifies different tax rates based on income brackets, ranging from 18% to 26% for various income levels. Tax rates based on income brackets are as follows:
- Over $60,000: $18,200 plus 28% of the excess over $80,000
- Over $80,000 but not over $100,000: $23,800 plus 30% of the excess over $100,000
- Over $100,000 but not over $150,000: $38,800 plus 32% of the excess over $150,000
- Over $150,000 but not over $250,000: $70,800 plus 34% of the excess over $250,000
- Over $250,000 but not over $500,000: $155,800 plus 35% of the excess over $500,000 The lifetime gift exemption under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to $10,000,000, with an inflation adjustment for calendar years after 2011. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the cost-of-living for calendar years after 2011 by substituting 'calendar year 2010' for 'calendar year 2016'. Rounding rules apply if the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $10,000. Other amendments related to gift tax include changes to section headings and table items. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the cost-of-living for calendar years after 2011. Changes include adjustments to gift tax provisions such as amendments to section headings and table items. Additionally, amendments are made to sections 2505 and 2801(a)(1) regarding the credit against gift tax and the effective date of the changes. A transition rule is also established for the application of sections 1015(d), 2502, and 2505, treating the calendar year of enactment as two separate calendar years. The calendar year of enactment is treated as one preceding calendar period for applying section 2504(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
